titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I walked my ordinary rounds before Breakfast and before dinner— Morning visits from Mr Fisher with Mr Barthe and Mr Ducorneau— These two Gentlemen have just arrived from Moscow— Mr Barthe was here the summer before last, and then returned to America— Last Summer he arrived at Archangel from Philadelphia— Had also a visit from Mr Hazard, who dined with us— He goes to-morrow for Archangel.— I read the Sermons 4. and 5. of the English Preacher Vol. 5.—they are both by Seed and two of the best in the Collection, or that I ever read— One on Domestic Union, and the other on the pursuit of Wisdom— They are in the calm, reasoning manner of English preaching; mere moral discourses, but written with great elegance, and urging serious truths with ingenuity, accurate observation of human nature, and a highly polished style.— In the Evening I read several Sections of Paley’s Horae Paulinae; in which there is great research, close examination of all Paul’s Epistles; an acute comparison of different passages of them together, for the elucidation of all, and resulting from the whole a strong argument of their authenticity; and an high eulogium of the Apostle—

2. Rose at 5. and walked before Sun-rise— It made for me a couple of morning hours which I employed in writing— The Chevalier de Bray, called upon me, and invited me to dine with him this day— Had a visit also from Mr Harris— Miss Bode dined with the Ladies— I dined at Monsieur de Bray’s— Count St: Julien, Chevalier’s Lebzeltern and Berks were there; Count Bose, and several Strangers— Mr Prevost of the French Embassy was also there— After dinner Madame de Bray was very urgent with Count St: Julien to persuade him to give a Ball; but he said it was Lent in his Country— Before I returned home I called at the Chevalier Bezerra’s; but he and his Lady were both abroad; they shortly after came and paid us an Evening visit— It is the first day that Mr Bezerra has been able to come out since the Balcony scene of the Empress’s birth-day— He was as usual full of news. We closed the Evening with Cards.

3. In my second walk; before dinner, I met the Emperor, who said he had not seen me for a long time;—and he supposed we walked at different hours— I told him that I had adopted the practice of walking in the morning early; and sometimes saw his Majesty window open, in very cold weather— He said that he always made it a rule to rise in the morning, and dress with his window open— I asked if he did not suffer from the Cold— He said on the contrary he found it enured him better than any thing to the Cold— That in the time of the Empress Catherine it had been very much the usage to be shut up and confined in hot apartments; and in that of the late Emperor, on the contrary to be continually out at the parades, and there were not as at present large buildings where the exercises were held— He had then worn a flannel waistcoat; but he found it irritated and fretted the skin so much, and made him so delicate that he could not endure it— A Physician therefore advised him to leave it off, and told him that either he would die under the
operation of the change, or would have his health much better— He left off therefore the maudite veste de flannelle; he did not die; but has had his health much better; and been wholly free from certain rhumatic complaints that he had been subject to, before. You are not of my opinion said he, about flannel?— I said that I had so long been in the custom of wearing it in Winter; that I believe if I should leave it off, I should die under the operation— But, said he, there are now many physicians here who think, that flannel is a bad thing for wear— I was not interrupted at home—made some further progress in Paucton; and wrote part of a letter— Cards at the close of the Evening.

4. Count Löwenhielm, a son of the old Count who was Swedish Minister at the Hague when I resided there, and now an Aid de Camp General of the king of Sweden, arrived here about a fortnight since, with a special Mission to the Emperor. He came accompanied by a Mr Brandel— Last week I received their Cards and sent mine in return. This day Count Löwenhielm called upon me, and delivered a letter from Baron Engeström to me; which he had given as introductory to Mr Brandel— Morning visit also from Mr Montreal and the Ladies had evening visits from Madame de Betancourt and her daughters; and from Madame Colombi— I finished a short letter, begun yesterday, and read a very few pages in Paucton.

5 I received this morning a letter from Mr: Anderson at Gothenburg enclosing one for the Chevalier de Bray— I returned the visit of Count Löwenhielm, who lodges at the Hotel de l’Europe; but was not at home. I left Cards for him and for Mr Brandel; and also for the Minister of Wurtemburg, Count Frohberg, who lodges at the same house— I called on the French Ambassador. The Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin was with him, to give him information concerning the exhibition at the school for noble young ladies to-morrow— He left him soon; but immediately afterwards came in Coll: Knesebeck the Prussian Officer, lately arrived here on a special mission—he said he should leave the City upon his return, to-morrow Evening— I went to Monsieur de Bray’s house, and left the letter for him; I afterwards met him walking on the quay; and he walked with me. I called also at Mr Schenbom’s and Mr Henry Severin’s, but both were unwell and did not receive me— Mr Harris called this morning and invited me to dine with him— There were Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner, Barthe and Norman— In the Evening I paid a visit to the Chevalier and Madame Bezerra; he was going out; and was full of the Storm of Cuidad Rodrigo, by Lord Wellington— He read me part of the London Gazette Extraordinary of 5. Feby. containing the official accounts; and I found Mr Bezerra had read more attentively the French Official reports, which came with the newspapers yesterday than I had— He rectified some erroneous conclusions that I had drawn from them— When I came home we had Cards the rest of the Evening.

6. The invitation to the examination of the young Ladies of noble families at the Convent was with notice to begin at 9. O’Clock. in the morning. I went with Mr Smith, before ten, and found they had already begun— The examination was then in Geometry; after which followed experimental philosophy; French Rhetoric and Literature—German language— Then the Company were introduced into another Hall, where were the samples of drawing, painting, needle work, embroidery, and artificial flowers, worked by the young Ladies— Then we returned to the Examination Hall, and the musical performances commenced; after which succeeded the dancing, and the whole concluded about four O’Clock— Part of the Company then went into another apartment, where a Collation was provided, and the young Ladies presented the plates round to the guests— The examinations were precisely the same, as at the Institution of St: Catherine last year; and chiefly if not altogether by the same Masters— The music, especially the singing I thought better now than then—the dancing, and the works of art, not so good— The Geometry, Physics, Literature and Languages much the same—lessons learnt by heart, and generally well repeated— All spoke French well, and with evident facility— Several compositions were distributed, of which I received three; two of them however by the same person—one a friendly letter to a friend, with topics of consolation upon the loss of an Aunt, and her Fortune—one a sentimental eulogy of Benevolence—and one a short argument upon the existence of deity, founded on the visible things of Creation— The hand-writing very good, and entirely formed— The style correct and easy—they are in the French language— The number of young Ladies who quit the school and whose names were on the Programme of the exhibition was 104.— There is also a certain number of demoiselles Bourgeoises, that is not of noble families, educated at this same Seminary; but their examination is to be to-morrow, and the foreign Ministers are not invited to attend it— They are educated nearly in the same manner, with the omission of Logic, Geometry and experimental philosophy— It was observed now as well as last year, that there were very few handsome girls among them, and Count St: Julien next to whom I sat remarked that they had all ignoble
countenances— But he said there was no nobility in this Country— That as the Government was a mere despotism, every man was all or nothing as the Sovereign smiled or frowned— Birth was nothing.— But as he came from the Court of Vienna, where Birth was in high estimation, it was natural for him to entertain different opinions— This produced a Conversation between us, upon noble blood and noble faces, in which I did not much indulge the noble Maltese Commandeur’s pride of Birth; and in which he indulged himself with it to his own satisfaction; acknowledging at last that there was too much truth in the reasons which I assigned to him, for not thinking that the alliance between noble blood and noble countenances was universal or even general, in any part of Europe— There were some Cabardinians, Tartars, there in the dresses of their Country, two with large white turbans, and the rest with sharp pointed velvet caps, like those in Chinese pictures—Georgians, Circassians, Mingrelians, Turks, and so forth as usual— General Watzdorf soon retired, it being his Post-day— On returning home I found Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham here; Mr Ingraham untill within these few days has been confined more than two Months with the rhumatism— Mr Harris paid us a visit of two hours in the Evening— At the Exhibition I met Count Löwenhielm, who introduced to me Mr Brandel, and Coll: Stiernkroon, an Aid de Camp of the Prince Royal of Sweden, lately arrived here.

7. Dined with the French Ambassador, and a Company of about twenty persons— In the Evening I paid visits at the Chevalier Bezerra’s, Mr Laval’s, and Mr Krehmer’s, but was no where received— After I returned home Madame Bezerra paid a long Evening visit to our Ladies. At the exhibition yesterday, the large Hall of the performances was excessively warm; while the other Hall’s where the manual works were exposed and where the Collation was served were almost as cold, as the external air— I still find it impossible to go from a warm room to a cold one without taking Cold; and this day I suffer the effects of having made that change yesterday.— I read a little in Paucton, and wasted the rest of the day.

8. Morning visit from Count Frohberg, the Minister of the king of Würtemberg, who expects the War to break out from day to day, in which case he will be among those that must depart— I finished reading Paley’s Horae Paulinae, which is a strong argument in support of Christianity— Under the simple form of a collation of passages between the Acts of the Apostles, and St: Paul’s Epistles it contains an high panegyric upon the Apostle of the Gentiles himself, and barely touches but with great force upon the strength of Evidence which results from St: Paul’s History, in favour of Christianity— I read also Sermons 6 and 7. Vol. 5. of the English Preacher—on Persecution, and on Charity— The Ladies paid several Evening visits.

9. I had a morning visit from Mr Brandel— I called upon the General of the Jesuits Brzozowsky, to deliver him a letter I had received for him from New-York—from one of the fathers he sent out last Summer— I found the old father reading his Breviary, and he made me excuses for asking me to wait untill he had finished; which he did in a few minutes. I told him that father Malou who inclosed to me the letter for him had also written to me, mentioning that they had commenced a school, but were in great want of more teachers— The General answered that he could not supply them— That from all quarters he was called upon for fathers, and had none to spare— The Ecclesiastical life was now pursued by very few persons; the military Career was the only one in favour— He spoke to me about Waldstein; saying he had heard I had been robbed by a servant; and asked if he was a Russian. I said a Livonian. Ah! said he, and so a Lutheran!— But observing I suppose that I was not pleased with the remark, by my looks, he added that it would have given him great pain if he had been a Catholic; because those who were Catholics ought to prove themselves worthy of their religion— It was evident however that the old man thinks a man’s being a protestant is a solution for every enormity committed by him— Madame de Bray the other day attributed it all to Waldstein’s being an affranchi— That said she, is the consequence of giving those people their freedom— Madame de Bray is the daughter of a Livonian nobleman, who probably relishes evidence against the emancipation of his peasants, as the Jesuit is a Catholic Churchman, who thinks Luther the root of all evil— Such is the mode of reasoning among men and women— I dined with Baron Blome; the company about eighteen persons— Count Löwenhielm and the other Swedish Gentlemen were there— General Watzdorf told me he had a Congé, to go home in May— Rayneval instead of talking politics played and sung a duet from il Matrimonio Segreto, with Mr Soldan— I called at Mr Bezerra’s in the Evening on my return home, but he was abroad— Mr Woodward came and pass’d an hour of the Evening with us— I received from Count Romanzoff a large packet, with the remainder of the dispatches forwarded to me by Mr Barlow from Paris; and some additional letters— One from my Mother, of 5. January—

10. Walked before Breakfast, and afterwards to purchase glass at the Imperial depot. The newspapers last Night received, absorbed the greater part of the day—and Paucton, with further metrological enquiries, the remainder— I am endeavouring to ascertain the contents of an Anchor; and a Stoff— These are measures of liquids here— I bottled an anchor of Wine, and ascertained as nearly as I could its contents
in cubic inches— But I only come to approximations.— Mr Harris, Mr Fisher, Mr Ingraham and Mr Cunningham, passed the Evening with us, and the Ladies entertained us with Music.

11. Morning walk; and the Spring is approaching.— Count Löwenhielm, Coll: Sternkroon and Mr Brandel—Chevalier Bezerra, his Lady and Captain Guedes, General Watzdorf, Count Bussche, Chevalier Brancia, Mr Jouffroy, and Mr Harris dined with us— Mr Bezerra’s family and Mr Harris also spent the Evening with us, and we had Cards— Madame Colombi and her Sister—Don Francisco, and Mr Zea also pass’d the Evening with us; our company finally left us about one in the morning— Count Chernicheff arrived last Evening as a Courier from Paris; and there was a great variety of news— The War is universally expected

12. The Chevalier Brancia called upon me this morning, and read to me all the official Correspondence that has passed both at Naples, and here respecting the duel between Prince Dolgorucki and Baron Durand, the Russian and French Ministers at Naples; and he told me what he had done here on the occasion— It was at the Diplomatic Circle, on New-Year’s day— The Neapolitan Minister of foreign Affairs relates the transaction in an instruction to Mr Brancia— That on the new year’s day, when the Corps Diplomatique was passing from the Salle des Ambassadeurs to the Salle du Trone, preceded by the Maitre des Ceremonies Prince Dolgorucki and Baron Durand were going first, side by side, and the Prince having the right hand, when they came to the door of the Salle du Trone, before the Grand Maitre des Ceremonies had taken the king (Murat)’s orders to introduce them, and before the door-keeper had opened the door, the Prince pushed it open and entered, which Baron Durand attempting to prevent, the Prince in presence of the king, struggled to keep his place, and laid his hand upon his sword—he maintained his place— The king had presence of mind to avoid manifesting his indignation at this indecent scene, but addressing both the Ministers said that he could only ascribe what had pass’d to their eagerness, each to be the first to present his felicitations to him; and then conversed with them both on other topics; but as soon as the levee was over, he expressed his displeasure in the most energetic manner, and directed depositions to be taken, and enquiries of the other members of the diplomatic Corps who had been present, to be made, concerning the facts, and finding them attested to be as above stated, although he had on all other occasions been perfectly satisfied with the conduct of Prince Dolgorucki, he could not overlook a proceeding so offensive, and had forbidden Prince Dolgorucki’s appearance at Court, untill the Emperor’s orders could be taken—the latter then instructed Brancia, to demand the Prince’s recall— He omitted reading the instructions— With it were enclosed the depositions to the facts, and the Correspondence between the Neapolitan Minister of foreign Affairs and Prince Dolgorucki on the subject— The former stating to the Prince, the king’s displeasure at the scene that had taken place, observing that if the king had not assigned to the foreign Ministers their respective ranks of precedence, that he had a right to treat as a family representative the Minister of his august brother the Emperor of the French, and that he could not but express his resentment at an insult offered to him— That the king therefore had determined to demand of the Emperor the Prince’s recall, and in the mean time had directed the Minister to signify to the Prince that it would be proper to abstain from attendance at Court— The Prince in his answer expresses his great regret that the king should have taken displeasure at any thing in his conduct. Says that he was bound not to submit to any pretension of precedence by the French Minister; and appeals to the express letter of an Article in the Treaty of Tilsit stipulating the most perfect reciprocity between the two powers— That he, the Prince having been at the right hand, and having on a former occasion declared his intention to take his precedence of the French Minister in turn, had advanced up to the door of the Hall, when the French Minister had thrown himself in his way, attempted to seize the handle of the door-latch, and to stop his passage, saying Ah! pour cela—cela ne sera pas— That he therefore was the cause of the struggle, in which the Prince necessarily was drawn to keep his place, and that if he had laid his hand upon his sword it was merely to disengage it from between his legs— That as to precedence on the principle of family representation it was allowable only to Ambassadors, and could not be pretended to by Ministers of the second order.— On receiving these papers, Mr Brancia requested an interview with Count Romanzoff; which he deferred one day later than usual, and in the mean time received a Courier from Naples, with Prince Dolgorucki’s own account of the transaction— On this he sent Mr Brancia, a Note, before the Conference; stating that the Emperor had learnt with much concern the dispute which had happened between Prince Dolgorucki, and the French Minister at Naples; and regretted that the king of Naples had thought proper, instead of simply asking his recall, to forbid his appearance at Court— That the Emperor might have used reprizals, but that consulting only his magnanimity and his amicable dispositions towards the king of the two Sicilies, he had resolved to continue his friendly relations with him as heretofore; and he the Count was ordered to declare to Mr Brancia, that he should continue to be received and treated at Court as he had been heretofore, and as if the unfortunate occurrences at Naples had never happened— When the interview took place, Brancia found Count Romanzoff, still dwelling upon Prince Dolgorucki’s exclusion from the Neapolitan Court, and expressing himself concerning it with some ill humour— He thought
it therefore necessary to answer the Count’s Note, stating to him that it was not on account of the duel, (the Count had spoken of that, as the occasion of what had happened) but of the outrage committed in the king’s presence, that the measure had been taken, of interdicting the Court to Prince Dolgorucki—and quoting a passage from Vattel, as authority for interdicting the Court to an offending foreign Minister, or even ordering him away from the Country— After this Count Romanzoff sent for Brancia again; and told him that his Note had been laid before the Emperor, who had weighed the observations contained in it, and recognizing that there was solidity in them, he had given orders that Prince Dolgorucki should be recalled, and had appointed Baron Budberg, to reside at Naples, in his stead; as Chargé d’Affaires.—and thus this matter is terminated— The duels were both subsequent to the interdiction of the Court, to Prince Dolgorucki— The day afterwards, Baron Durand sent Prince Dolgorucki a challenge— The Prince answered him that while invested with a diplomatic character, he did not think it proper to fight—but that he had already written home offering his resignation to the Emperor, which he had no doubt would be accepted, when he should readily meet the Baron— The Baron replied, that the Prince’s excuse for not fighting was not sufficient—that as they were both diplomatic characters, that circumstance took away the impropriety of a meeting between them in single combat, upon which he again insisted— The prince then yielded—they fought, and were both slightly wounded— A French General there at the time, likewise sent a challenge to Prince Dolgorucki; to which Mr Benkendorf the Secretary of the Russian Legation answered, that Prince Dolgorucki could not be expected to fight all the Frenchmen at Naples—but if the General was very desirous of a duel; he Benkendorf was ready to meet him in the Prince’s stead— They fought accordingly, and they too were both wounded— The two duels were on the same day— Benkendorf has since had the order of St: Wladimir conferred upon him by the Emperor— I intended to have written this day to Baron Engeström, but spent the day idly— In the Evening I was unwell.— By idleness I understand trifling with researches of weights and measures.

13. This morning I finished the perusal of the German Bible, which I began 20. June last— There are many differences of translation from either the English or the French Translations— Some of which I have compared in the three versions— Many passages obscure and even unintelligible to me in the English are clear in the French and German— Of the three, the German I think has the fewest of these obscurities— But the eloquence of St Paul strikes me as more elevated and sublime in the English than in either of the others. In the German New Testament there is a transposition in the arrangement of the Books— The Epistle to the Hebrews being separated from the rest of St Paul’s, and placed after those of Peter and John— There is a difficulty which obviously often embarrassed all the Translators; it was how to render the significant proper names which abound in the Bible— For instance in the text where Adam says in the English Bible that Eve “shall be called Woman, because she was taken out of man” the name does not correspond with the reason assigned for giving it— II. Gen. 23.— The French Bible has it “on la nommera Hommesse, car elle a été prise de l’homme”— The name and the reason here correspond, but hommesse is not the french word for woman—there is no such word in the language—the German Bible resorts to the same expedient of coining a word, and says she shall be called Männin if the English translators had taken the same liberty they would have called her Manness— In expressions of this sort the English Translators whenever they can retain the very Hebrew word; and sometimes they give as proper names, words which the other translators render as things— The more I read the Bible the more I feel that it ought to be accompanied with critical and explanatory Notes— There are Commentators and Expositors enough; but they are too voluminous; and almost universally sectaries: whose labours are devoted not to explanation but to controversy— The German Bible has one very useful kind of annotation. It is that after every verse throughout the Book, all the other verses having reference to it are marked down— This is peculiarly convenient for consulting the mutual references between the Old and New Testament—the Prophecies and their fulfilment— The German New Testament also besides the division of the Books into Chapters marks the festivals at which particular Epistles and Gospels are to be read; at the passages themselves. There is at the commencement both of the French and German Bibles an excellent discourse upon the manner and dispositions in which the Scriptures should be read—that of the German Bible is the best.— Mr Montreal paid me a morning visit— The Ladies spent the Evening at Madam Colombi’s and Charles was left with me.— I find it difficult to employ his time, and when with me he entirely engrosses mine— I endeavour to amuse him, and at the same time to convey instruction to his mind through the medium of every thing that happens— But it is not always easy to discriminate between the knowledge suitable to his age, and the solid nourishment of maturer years— He often asks questions, which it is impossible to answer to his understanding; as do all children of good natural parts— My rule is, to answer them always truly; and as I should to a grown person; explaining what I can make him understand, but freely using terms which I know he cannot, when they are necessary to the definition— If he does not
take the whole idea, he usually gets part of it, and seldom pushes the enquiry any further. I believe that all complex ideas must be thus acquired by parts at a time; and that they can only be completed, by the frequent repetition of their recurrence— By giving however some of these fragments, much beyond the comprehension of a Child, they are apt to associate themselves in his mind with the ideas which are lodged there, and the combination produces absurdities which may be liable to run eventually into errors of judgment or paradoxical opinions— Socrates says in one of Plato’s dialogues, that he is only a midwife to the minds of his disciples— This Talent is perhaps the most essential of all that can contribute to form an accomplished teacher— How much I would wish to possess it— I give Charles a large portion of my Time; and I would fain have it prove profitable to him— He had the whole of this Evening.

14. Mr Strugowtshikoff my landlord called upon me this morning— He is a Russian of the Class of Society between the principal nobility and the mere common People—a Class by no means numerous in this Country; and of which he is in truth the only one I know; for the Glukoff’s, are in some respects above, and in others below it— This man speaks French and German, well but with difficulty— And he inclines to talk with considerable freedom about public affairs— I paid him half a year’s rent in advance, and he told me that in a few days he should have to pay almost the whole of it as a tax, to the City. The House was rated at 110000 Rubles, and taxed at 1 per Cent on that sum, and he had to pay both for the last year and the present, with six per Cent interest upon the last years payment— The tax had formerly been only 1/2 per Cent, and payment might be delayed for years, incurring only the interest of 6 per Cent for the delay— Now the tax was doubled, and payment was to be enforced on the penalty of confiscation— He also complained that the Brandy-farmers cheated the people, by selling them Water instead of Spirits— I asked him if there was no inspection— He said yes; but the inspectors were bribed— That the system of bribery was graduated from the highest to the lowest officers, and the poor People, were the victims of them all.— I took Charles out with me to the Gachellies, upon the river— They are the same that are exhibited at Easter time on the Isaac Square— The tight-rope dancers— Chinese Shadows and Transparent Arabian fire-works— Charles, who was frightened at them last Easter-week so that I was obliged to send him home, was now so much pleased with them that he urged strongly to see the fourth— But they had not opened their door for entrance, and it was drawing towards five O’Clock. I had engaged company to dinner, and was obliged to come home— The ice-hills, opposite the fortress were very much thronged— Those below the winter-Bridge, not so much— The procession of sledges round the corner of the Palace, was longer than I had seen it before.— We walked home— Mr Montreal, Mr Barthe and Mr Ducorneau dined, and spent the Evening with us— Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham had promised to come, but Fisher at 5 O’Clock sent an excuse— Mr Smith dined abroad.

15. Snow-storm the whole day, which confined me to the house, excepting a ride with Charles before dinner.— It was the last day of the Russian Butter-week, when they partly fast, and partly frolic—when Mascarades and Plays follow in succession from nine in the morning till Midnight. I saw little of it, the procession of sledges not having commenced when we rode out— Mr E. Plummer, returned from Moscow, and Mr Cutts again from Archangel paid me a morning visit.— I read Sermons 8 and 9. Vol. 5. of the English Preacher— On the frailty of human Nature; and on Self-Government— Also several chapters in Watts’s improvement of the mind— A book so highly commended by Dr Johnson, and which I have been at least seventeen years intending to read, whenever I could find time— From the part of it which I this day read, I think it will fully answer my expectations— The style is agreeable, and sufficiently ornamented; with a frequent introduction of fictitious characters to illustrate observations upon faults and vices, which give the work a sort of dramatic effect— The language is sometimes incorrect; but the author never completed his plan, and the second part of the Book is a posthumous publication— I should have mentioned yesterday that I began the second reading of the French Bible, with Ostervald’s reflections after each chapter— Some of these reflections are just and as hints for improvement, may be useful— But they scarcely ever explain any thing, and sometimes to guard against irreverend inferences they are not altogether consistent with truth— They speak for instance of the marriage of Abraham with Hagar; though afterwards they call Keturah Abraham’s second wife.— There is no occasion to trench upon truth in honour of the Bible or of Bible characters

16. Another day of snow.— The french Ambassador sent me this morning a note to say that he should dispatch this Evening a Courier, for Paris— I wrote a few lines to Mr Barlow and to Mr Gray, and with them enclosed a letter for my brother— I took the packet with me, and left it at the Ambassador’s as I was going out to dine at Mr Raimbert’s— Mr Smith and Charles went with me— Messrs: Barthe, Ducorneau, Chastelgué, and David dined there— I returned home early in the Evening, being not well— Count Löwenhielm and Mr Brandel, both paid us long evening visits— The Count had been dining with the Emperor; The Russian lent began this morning; and the Count was not delighted with his fare— The Emperor himself keeps lent, but has meat served at table for guests who do not— The Roman Catholic lent, will not begin untill Wednesday— The Greek Church does not keep Shrove Tuesday. Count Lowenhielm said he had been at both the masquerades yesterday; of noon and Evening— To-morrow Evening there will be two more—

17. Third day of Snow, which confined me again to the house, excepting a short walk before dinner— Morning visit from Mr Haven, upon his return from Moscow— Most of this day was occupied with the settlement of monthly accounts, and with Paucton’s Metrology.— His account of the measures used by the Antients is of great curiosity; but he does not sufficiently quote his authorities— He says that the standard of antient measures was taken from an aliquot part of the Circumference of the Earth; and that it formed the basis of all their weights and measures— He proposes to restore this system, as the French have since actually done— He argues much from the basis of the Great Pyramid, which was exactly one great Olympic Stadium, and from the Devak or Nilometer, which he considers as the standard of a cubit— He speaks with irreverence and even with ill-temper of Pliny the Naturalist, for his inattention to the accuracy of weights and measures— And he has many very interesting observations upon measures taken from certain parts of the human body, and from the ordinary pace of a middle sized man— My own experiments agree very accurately with the result of his.

18. The sky cleared away in the Night, and this morning the thermometer was at 10 degrees below 0. I took therefore my walk before breakfast which I had omitted for several days— On my return home I found the father General of the Jesuits who had brought me a letter to be forwarded to father Malou at New-York.— After Breakfast Mr Barthe and Mr Ducorneau paid me a visit— They are about returning to Moscow— A black man came to ask assistance from me which I could not give him— He belonged to the Angerona, Captain Marks one of the ships, seized for coming with false papers— He says he can neither get his wages nor a discharge— I gave him a line of recommendation to Mr Harris.— Charles and Paucton employed my day— I concluded upon my wife’s persuasion, to write to America to have our two eldest sons sent to us here, if it can be done without extraordinary danger. Mr Harris paid us an Evening visit.

19. The black man who was here yesterday came again this morning, and can obtain no relief at least for the present from Mr Harris— He has no means of subsistance untill the Summer, and asked me to take him to attend and serve in my family, for his lodging and subsistence without wages untill the Navigation shall be open, and he can procure employment as a seaman to return to America— I concluded to take him accordingly. His name is Peter Cook, and he was born in Kent County Maryland— I called upon Mr Harris, to make the necessary arrangement respecting his Passport— Walked afterwards upon the Quay, and met the Emperor— He told me he had seen one of our Americans this Morning, who must have very strong military propensities, for he had gone out, when there were at least 15 degrees of frost, to see one of the Regiments march—which were leaving the City— He meant Mr Fisher— I said he had perhaps some acquaintance among the Officers. . . No! not in that Regiment. . . But he is acquainted with Mr Fenshaw, who belongs to the Regiment that will go next Saturday. . . And so it is, continued his Majesty— After all, that War is coming, which I have done so much to avoid— Every thing. . . I have done every thing, to prevent this struggle (cette lutte.) but thus it ends. . . But, said I, are all hopes vanished of still preserving the Peace?. . . At all Events said he, we shall not begin the War. . . My will is yet to prevent it; but we expect to be attacked— Then, said I, as your Majesty has determined not to commence, I would fain hope, it may still pass over without a War—. . . I wish it may, said he. . . “Mais tous les indices sont à la guerre”. . . Et puis. . .il avance toujours. . . Il a commencé par prendre la Pomérarie Suédoise. . . voila qu’a présent il vient d’occuper la Prusse. . . il ne peut pas beaucoup plus avancer sans nous attaquer— I said it was to be hoped he would be stopped somewhere. . . Oh! Oui!. . . j’espère bien quil ne viendra pas jusqu’ici. . . Seven or eight regiments have already marched from St: Petersburg, within the last three weeks, for the frontiers, and others are following twice or three times each week.— In the Evening we had visits from the Chevalier Bezerra and Captain Guedes— Count St: Julien, and Mr Woodward.— Paucton and the Métrologie primitive, still engross all my leisure— I have been for years uncertain of the exact comparison between the length of the French and English foot; which is yet essential to ascertain that of all the new French weights measures and Coins— I have at last found that in the Philosophical Transactions of the year 1768 a Mr Bird gives the English foot as equal to 135.116115.4 lines and decimals of the Pied de la Toise du Perou, the identical measure by which the Metre of the new French system was compared, when finally established— I shall therefore in future take this proportion as the standard, though Paucton, Ricard and Dubost make the English foot 3/10000 longer.— Bird’s calculation being carried to seven decimals of a line, and referring expressly to the Toise du Perou— The difference between the two Calculations trifling as it seems produced one of eleven feet in a myriameter, and nearly two feet upon an English Mile— On the Circumference of the Earth it amounts to a difference of nearly ten miles—

20. I took this morning a longer walk than usual for the purpose of measuring by the number of my paces, and by time taken to walk it the distance between the first and second Verst Column on the Czarsko zelo road— I found it as on a former occasion 1366 paces, but I walked it in 11 minutes—the cold having quickened my step.— Paucton states the pace of a man 5 feet 2 1/2 inches french, tall
to be 2 1/3 feet or 28 inches pied du Roi, and at the rate of 121 in a minute— My own height is 2 feet 7 inches English about 1/2 an inch higher than Paucton’s standard; and I have found by experiments frequently repeated that my ordinary pace is 2 feet 6 inches and 88/100 of an inch or about 29 french inches, and that in my ordinary pace I walk 120 steps to a minute— My height thus exceeds that of Paucton about 1/120 and my gait advances upon his about 1/40— But I have never had an opportunity of comparing my step by a distance regularly measured, and I know the Mile-Stones and Verst Stones have been carelessly placed— I had a morning visit from Mr Montréal, and in the Evening from Mr Lebzeltern— I was quite unwell the whole day.

21. I rose with the dawn, and walked out, but the snow soon obliged me to return— There is a passage in Paucton, which is either incorrect, or which I cannot comprehend; and as it is in a matter of calculation, I have been several days arrested at it; by the endeavour to possess myself of it— I spent this whole morning upon it— Before dinner I called at three Booksellers shops for tables of logarithms— I found them, only at one place.— In the Evening I read some pamphlets lent me by Mr Prevost respecting Etienne’s Comedy of the two Sons in Law— The Ladies, with Charles much against his will, went to take a Russian Bath— I have a cold, hoarseness and sore throat.

22. The changes of temperature in the atmosphere are still sudden, violent, and frequent— It thawed almost the whole of yesterday; this morning when I rose—between 6 and 7 it snowed, and scarcely froze— Cleared off before our breakfast time, and at night there were 15 degrees of frost— I walked before dinner— The sun was clear, but the air very Cold. I had no interruption but from Charles— Read further in Watts on the improvement of the Mind— His remarks upon learning Languages, upon the practice of learning Latin from Horace, Ovid, and Juvenal, upon syllogistic disputes of which he gives a very minute description, and upon the Socratic method are all deserving of great consideration— I do not however concur in all his opinions; and particularly I question the justness of that which led him to recommend Buchanan’s Latin translation of the Psalms, as a school-Book.— He treats the heathen mythology, and indeed his subject generally rather too much as a divine; and not quite enough as a literary teacher— The protestant at least, if not the sectarian theologist is too much discovered in his instructions; I should have liked the Book much better, if the Pantheon, and Transubstantiation, and Fate, freewill, foreknowledge absolute had been all omitted— There is however so much sterling good sense and so much sound principle mixed up with these defects that I regret not having read this book before, and wish it may not prove useless to me now— I also read Sermons 10. 11. Vol 5. of the English preacher— On the security of uprightness, and on the use of riches.

23. I walked this morning before Breakfast, although the thermometer was at 16.5 degrees below 0— I had morning visits from the two Messrs: Plummer, with Mr Andrew from Archangel, from Mr Harris and Mr Woodward— He proposed to have an arrangement made with the house of Messrs Raimbert, to secure the property which they have in Commission belonging to Mr Gray; on the contingency of a French War which is now extremely imminent. I approved of this and had recommended it some months ago to Mr Woodward— I called again at my Russian booksellers, and at Etter’s to see if I could find any large tables of logarithms, but without success— Etter had some curiosities which tempted me, but not sufficiently to overcome the resistance of a scanty purse— I spent the first part of the Evening in attempting to amuse Charles and to teach him to read numbers, and the latter part at Cards with the Ladies

24— Anniversary of the Emperor’s accession, but as usual it was not particularly noticed— I went round to the Bookseller’s, and finally took the Tables of Callet, which I had renounced on Saturday— I took Charles with me in the Sleigh, and after calling at the French Ambassadors and leaving Mr Prevost’s pamphlets, walked home— In the morning I had a visit from Mr Montréal, and in the Evening from Mr Lebzeltern, who brought with him and introduced a Prince Kosloffsky, who has been sometime the Russian Chargé d’Affairs in Sardinia. He talked much about the discussions between the British and American Governments on the subject of neutral and belligerent rights— The Ladies went out with Charles to see the illuminations, which were principally at the French Ambassadors— Charles came home quite unwell.

25. Morning visit from Mr Woodward, and in the Evening from the two brothers Plummer— Owing to the severity of the cold I did not go out early in the morning, but walked before dinner— I met Monsieur and Madame de Bray with Countess Liewen walking upon the Quay.— Paucton and Callet still absorb all the time that has no indispensable occupation; and even encroach much upon that which ought to have one— Paucton engages my Curiosity more and more; but since I have detected him in a considerable error in his estimation of the English foot, my confidence in his calculations generally has been a little shaken— One strongly marked character of his book is singularity, and his method is not that of mathematical precision— He is much addicted to digression, and sometimes turns to subjects the connection of which with that of his work is not easily traced— He has for instance a Chapter to prove that the
American Continent was known to the Antients— What concert has this with weights and measures— I have not yet found sufficient proof of what he affirms as his fundamental position, that the Geometrical foot of the antients was the standard of all their weights measures and Coins, and that it was originally one four-hundred thousandth part of a degree of the Meridian— He affirms also that all the measures of distance were formed upon the proportions of limbs of a man of middling stature— He does not give his authorities in proof—nor does he reconcile together his two principles— For what need was there of the degree, if the proportions of the human form were the standard;—and what need of the proportions if the degree gave the measure?— There is frequent reference to the measures mentioned in the Bible, and an estimate of them all, compared with the old French measures. We had Cards at Night— Charles is still quite unwell.

26. Walked my six miles tour before breakfast; the cold by the thermometer was not below three degrees of frost; but the snow in the atmosphere made me as sensible to it as if there had been 10 or 12— It snowed even before I returned, and all the rest of the day— I had a morning visit from Mr Ecky and an evening one from Mr Woodward— Mr Ecky has sent a quantity of indigo, that he had here for sale, to Vienna— Within the last year a very brisk exportation from this Country to Vienna has been established— The goods are carried all the way by land on small sledges or waggons each drawn by one man, and having one driver to six of the Carriages— They go through Moscow and Kiew to Brody, and thence to Vienna.— The distance is nearly two thousand Miles, and they perform the Journey in about sixty days.— The advance on the prices of the goods at Vienna, more than defrays the charges— We had Cards in the Evening— Paucton and Callet absorbed the rest of the day.

27. The Snow continued the whole of this day, and I kept house— Mr Montreal was here in the morning, and Prince Koslofsky in the Evening— Charles has a slow intermitting fever, for which Dr Galloway this day prescribed an emetic— It appears to be a return of the same or a similar disease to that he had in December and January— I have also had a return of mine during the last ten days— I wrote this day a small part of a letter and gave the Evening entirely to Prince Koslofsky and to Charles’s amusement. the Prince though an Officer of the Legion of Honour is a warm politician, and expresses his abhorrence without disguise or reserve— He is full of Conversation, and takes pleasure in speaking English. He has a great desire to go out as Russian Minister to America, and appeared not well pleased that Mr Daschkoff had been appointed.

28. Morning visit from Mr Montréal— Mr Ecky and Mr Woodward also came to request Passports for Vienna and for Paris to be endorsed by the French Ambassador and Austrian Minister.— I went to Weyher the Booksellers shop, suspecting from an inspection of the Copy of Callet’s Tables I had taken there, that it was incomplete, and upon referring to other copies of the same tables, I found my suspicion well founded— The last half sheet of the Book was missing from my Copy, which he accordingly exchanged for another.— I then went for a few minutes to a public Auction of Books and Pictures; but found them selling the pictures— Walked round the Fontanka and Neva-Quays— Dined with General Watzdorf, and a diplomatic Company—of nineteen or twenty persons. Counts Lauriston and St: Julien, the Chevalier de Bray and Baron Blome, Colonels Chernicheff and Vlodek were there— The Ambassador told me that there was still all possible Courtesy in the personal Correspondence between the two Emperors; but that the kings of Spain, Naples, Westphalia, and the Vice-Roy of Italy were summoned to Paris to hold an assemblée de famille.— In the Evening I visited the Chevalier and Madame Bezerra— He had dined at Mr Laval’s but came home while I was at his house— He is sangwine in the expectation of the War, and reasons too much by his feelings to have a cool judgment. We had Cards at home to close the Evening.

29. Iwas reading this morning from Exodus 25 to 30. containing the description of the Tabernacle of the Covenant, the mercy seat, the altars of incense and burnt offering, the table and its furniture, with the Candlestick, and the dress for beauty and for glory, prescribed for Aaron and the Priests—a part of the Scriptures which I have always read cursorily and without much attention— I gave more to it now, and remarked not only the extreme and minute accuracy with which every thing is described, but the grandeur and sublimity of imagination, (if that word may be used) in the whole design— The profound impression of reverence and solemnity in the sacredness of the recess where the ark of the Covenant was to be deposited— The incitements to love as well as to adore the Creator, in the idea of placing the Mercy-Seat upon the ark— The attachment of the Nation to the Ministers of their Sanctuary and of the Priesthood to the Nation, inculcated by the precious stones engraved with the names of each of the twelve tribes of Israel, which he wore upon his shoulders, and in the Ephod upon his breast— The inscription Holiness to the Lord, on the front of his Mitre, and the Urim and Thummim, light and right, learning and integrity, covering his breast, combine altogether the whole duty of Man, Priest and People, in one emblematical lesson, which
seems to me calculated to take a stronger hold of human affections, and human reason than the whole system of Greek mythology, put together.— In the course of these chapters, I found mention made of the Zareth or Span—the Hin, and the Shekel of the Sanctuary, a measure of length, a measure of liquids, a weight and a Coin—besides a tenth deal of flour— I recurred to Paucton, who discusses all these points, and gives his estimate of these things— According to him the Hin was nearly 1 1/2 Gallon English wine-measure, and he says the Jewish Doctors say it was equal to 12. logs, or 72 hen’s egg-shells— He expressly quotes Rabbi Solomon upon 29. Exodus for this. The log he states at 0.4704 Paris Quarts—which is 27.444. Cubic inches, 1 1/2 Cubic inches short of an English pint.— But either the Egg-shells must have been conventional egg-shells, or the hens of Palestine must have laid larger eggs than those of Russia, or the estimate is too large— I made the experiment with an Egg shell this morning, and found it to contain 2 7/18 Cubic inches of Water. it would take therefore nine of them at least for the log, and 108. for the hin if they were of the capacity in Paris Quarts, (Pintes) mentioned by Paucton.— I also read the Sermons 12. and 13. Vol. 5. of the English Preacher—on the death of Christ and on Rashness of Judgment—and a few chapters of Watts on the Improvement of the Mind— Wrote a little— Walked in a fall of Snow, before dinner— Wrote a little—and received the notification of the decease of Prince Basile Dolgorucki, with an invitation to attend the funeral.

30. I perceive in reading Paucton this morning, that the hen’s egg shell, among the Hebrews was a definite measure of capacity, and of a given quantity— He says they called it a Besa, and that its contents were equal to 2 1/2 Roquilles of Paris, or nearly five English cubic inches.— I had a long visit this morning from Mr Bentzon, and we had one in the Evening from Mr Brandel. He told us that Mr Speransky was last evening dispatched for Siberia; with another distinguished person whose name he did not know— I employed at length a part of this day in writing.

31. At 9 O’Clock this morning Mr Smith went with me to attend the funeral of the late Prince Dolgorucki. We first proceeded to the house, and thence went in procession to the Monastery of St: Alexander Newsky— The funeral service was performed by the Metropolitan Ambrose, and resembled in every respect that for Prince Beloselsky— The only part of the ceremony that I now observed, and which had before escaped my attention was that just before the closing of the Coffin, the Metropolitan threw a small spoonful of dust into it— This is also the usage at interments according to the forms of the English Church— The Snow was so deep in the burying-yard, that the body was not carried out to it, but deposited in a chapel adjoining that where the ceremony was performed. It was about 2. O’Clock when we got home— I soon afterwards went out again, and paid a visit to Prince Kosloffsky— Called likewise at the French Ambassador’s, and at Count St: Julien’s, to get their endorsements on the Passports of Mr Ecky and Mr Woodward; but neither of them was at home.— I then walked untill nearly dinner time— Charles absorbed the Evening.

Day— The distribution of my time remains in general like that of the preceding Months— I rise about seven O’Clock— Read five Chapters in the Bible, and walk an hour and a half— Breakfast between ten and eleven— From which time untill five, our dining hour, my purpose is to do the business of the day— But the family concerns, Charles’s lessons, visits to receive or pay, newspapers, idleness and procrastination fill it up so constantly that it terminates in doing Nothing— The Evening has become equally barren of all profitable employment— I spend it in endeavouring to amuse and instruct Charles.
